lines.speaker: becky
lines.text: are you ready to get this international online conversation started??

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: I mean, I just started it right now by saying ‘hello’

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: no no, like, *really* start it.

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: oh, right, you haven’t actually received my message yet.

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: well, because you haven’t sent it!

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: I pressed Enter and all that, I don’t know if you saw

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: I did! but ‘hello’ still has to take the the journey all the way from New Zealand to the US.

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: do you want to do the honors, since you’re sending the message?

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: yeah, hang on

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: alright, ready to send whenever

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: let’s check the packet details just to be sure

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: hey! let’s take a closer look at this Salome situation.

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: I mean, I’m not *actually* sending a severed head

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: and a severed head wouldn’t be able to say hello

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: and also I would be dead

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: yes!

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: to all of that

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: anyway

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: this head-in-a-box is actually a **packet** that Zak is about to send me.

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: sending a packet is like sending physical mail––you still have an origin, a destination, and a message, but there’s some other stuff in there too.

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: Here's what it looks like.

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: so we can talk about the obvious ones first. Zak is the source and I’m the destination, except instead of our names we use our IP addresses.

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: well, that’s complicated too, because we’re probably using some kind of service like Twitter or Discord or Slack or something to have this conversation.

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: right, right. So Zak is actually sending the message from his IP address to [[redacted]]’s IP address

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: and then the server at [[redacted]] figures out who Zak is sending to, and then sends *me* a packet with the origin set to their server and the destination set to me.

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: but that makes this much more annoying

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: yeah, we’ll keep them out of this.

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: anyway, everything here except for “data” is the packet’s **header**.

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: 'version' is 4, because we’re using IPv4

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: the Internet Header Length (IHL) is exactly how long the header is in bytes.

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: there’s also the Total Length, which is the full length of the packet, including the data we care about

lines.speaker: Box
lines.text: “hello”

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: Type-of-Service is how we’d like the packet to be handled, in the sense of what priority it has. video or audio have higher priority because you want those to happen in time, but the timing of an email doesn’t need to be as precise

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: like shipping next-day versus three-day postage.

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: yeah!

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: then the next line has to do with fragmentation. Packets can only get so long, so if you need to send a lot of data (like a video, or this website), you have to split it up across a bunch of packets.

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: so if you have to chop up your cool video into **fragments**, each packet that’s got a bit of that video shares the same Identification code.

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: The Flag tells all the routers along the way that you’re sending fragmented data,

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: and the Fragmentation Offset tells you what part of the original data a given packet represents.

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: like a jigsaw puzzle with numbers on the back of each piece, so the router can put it back together really fast. not a very “fun” puzzle, but a very effective one

lines.speaker: Box
lines.text: “hello”

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: yeah, you’re not big enough to be fragmented, buddy

lines.speaker: Box
lines.text: “hello”

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: well, you never know. Fragmenting data into packets is really important––sending big chunks of data between two users would slow down the internet for everyone else on the line.

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: Anyways, the next chunk is Time-to-Live, which is a counter that drops by 1 for every router it comes across. If the TTL ever drops to 0, it gets dropped.

lines.speaker: Box
lines.text: “hello”

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: I mean, we’re not at the router yet, but if you keep doing that you might die sooner

lines.speaker: Box
lines.text: “hello”

lines.speaker: Box
lines.text: “hello”

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: the last two are what lower-level protocol is used to send the packet,

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: like ground mail vs air mail vs overseas

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: and every router the packet passes uses its Header Checksum to verify that the header contains what it ought to.

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: oh, and the message has to go in the “data” part.

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: yeah.

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: that’s

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: that’s where this gets more complicated. Every time you go to a webpage, it actually takes about 5-6 packets (not all IP packets!) to actually get the page contents, because you have to first find out where their server is based on the host name, then ask for their stuff, and then they have to send you their stuff in chunks, and then tell you they’re done sending you stuff.

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: did… did you want to go over all that?

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: no!!!

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: just assume that there’s a ton of junk in the data, but it could be any junk, because a packet could contain anything from a paragraph of text to a 30x30 section of an image.

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: let’s just get this head out the door

lines.speaker: Box
lines.text: “hello”

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: wait a sec

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: I know this packets-as-physical mail metaphor doesn’t match one-to-one with reality

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: but what’s our equivalent for postage?

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: I don’t know––I know I have to pay for internet service, but how that divides down to the packet level is beyond me

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: that’s a good question to ask, then

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: *'what does it cost to use the internet?*'
